We’ve talked a lot about KOSA, the “Kids Online Safety Act” that has massive bipartisan support in Congress. The latest version was introduced with 26 Senators as sponsors or co-sponsors. We’ve exp…

<h1 class="posttitle">
Heritage Foundation Says That Of Course GOP Will Use KOSA To Censor LGBTQ Content
</h1>
<div class="details">
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/?s&topic=policy">
<img class="topic_icon" src="https://www.techdirt.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/policy.jpg" />
</a>
<p>
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/?s&topic=policy">
Policy </a>
</p>
</div>
<h3>from the <i>democratic-support-censoring-lgbtq-speech</i> dept</h3>
<div class="byline">
<span class="pub_date">
Wed, May 24th 2023 12:26pm - </span>
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/user/mmasnick/" title="Posts by Mike Masnick" class="author url fn" rel="author">Mike Masnick</a>
</div>
<p>We’ve talked a lot about <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/kosa/">KOSA</a>, the “Kids Online Safety Act” that has massive bipartisan support in Congress. The latest version was introduced with <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/02/bipartisan-panic-26-senators-support-terrible-dangerous-unconstitutional-kosa-act/">26 Senators</a> as sponsors or co-sponsors. We’ve explained over and over again how the bill is unconstitutional and will actually do a lot to <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/19/yo-lizzo-youve-been-lied-to-kosa-will-harm-kids/">harm kids</a>.</p>
<p>Of course, like so many of these “bipartisan” anti-internet bills that have bipartisan support, the support on each side of the aisle is based on a very different view of how the bill will be used in practice. We went through this last year with the <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/aicoa/">AICOA</a> antitrust bill. Democrats supported it (falsely) believing that it would magically increase competition, while Republicans were gleefully talking about how they were going to use it to <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/2022/06/23/republicans-effectively-admit-that-if-content-moderation-is-written-out-of-antitrust-bills-theyll-pull-their-support/">force websites to host</a> their propaganda.</p>
<p>Now, with KOSA, again you have Democrats naively (and incorrectly) believing that because it’s called the “Kids Online Safety Bill” it will magically protect children, even though <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/2022/11/28/over-90-organizations-tell-congress-not-to-support-dangerous-kids-online-safety-bill/">tons of experts</a> have made it clear it will actually put them at <a target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/06/how-kosas-parental-tools-mandate-will-almost-certainly-lead-to-abuse/">greater risk</a>.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, Republicans are now freely admitting that they’re going to use KOSA to force websites to censor LGBTQ content. They’re literally proud of it. The Heritage Foundation, which at least used to have some principled stances before being taken over by culture warriors without any principles, is bragging about how it will use KOSA in this manner:</p>
<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter"><img decoding="async" src="https://i0.wp.com/lex-p.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/img/6f913aaa-1e14-45b2-bf25-34a754075cfc-RackMultipart20230523-6-p1i1q1.png?ssl=1" alt data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>
</div>
<p>In that tweet, Florence Ashley calls out an article on Heritage’s website laughably entitled “How Big Tech Turns Kids Trans” (which, um, is not how any of this works), and includes this paragraph:</p>
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote">
<p><em>Lawmakers can also help. Raising the minimum age for internet use (as the Child Online Privacy and Protection Act would do) may be one way to protect kids from online harms. <strong>Another step in the right direction would be to prohibit the sexual exploitation of minors and the promotion of content that poses risks to minors’ physical and mental health (which the Kids Online Safety Act would do).</strong> If we seek to protect kids online, we must guard against the harms of sexual and transgender content.</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Ashley, correctly calls out that they’re openly admitting how they’ll use KOSA to censor content. And Heritage replies in a quote tweet doubling down that this is exactly their plan:</p>
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote">
<p><em>Yes we do. Keeping trans content away from children is protecting kids. No child should be conditioned to think that permanently damaging their healthy bodies to try to become something they can never be is even remotely a good idea.</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Leaving aside that this framing is utter nonsense, it’s also none of lawmakers’ business what individuals and their doctors decide is the healthiest way forward for anyone.</p>
<p>So, um, seeing as over a dozen Democratic Senators, including Richard Blumenthal, Ben Ray Lujan, Tammy Baldwin, Amy Klobuchar, Gary Peters, John Hickenlooper, Chris Murphy, Chris Coons, Brian Schatz, Mark Warner, Peter Welch, Maggie Hasan, Dick Durbin, Sheldon Whitehouse, and Bob Casey are supporting, can anyone ask them <em>why</em> they’re supporting a bill that Republicans are saying directly they will use to silence LGBTQ speech?</p>
<p>Again, the enforcement mechanism in the bill is that state Attorneys General get to bring lawsuits against websites for not removing such “harmful” content. And if you don’t believe that there are GOP state AGs itching to bring exactly these lawsuits, you haven’t been paying attention.</p>
<p>I get that Blumenthal and Klobuchar have both made it clear that they <strong><em>don’t care</em></strong> one bit about how Republicans will use their bills to take away rights of the public, but could someone ask the others on that list why they’re supporting such a bill?</p>
<p class="filed">
Filed Under: <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/1st-amendment/" rel="tag">1st amendment</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/censorship/" rel="tag">censorship</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/gop/" rel="tag">gop</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/kosa/" rel="tag">kosa</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/lgbtq/" rel="tag">lgbtq</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/state-ags/" rel="tag">state ags</a>
<br/>
Companies: <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/company/heritage-foundation/" rel="category tag">heritage foundation</a>
</p>
</div>

<p>But then we’re still at 0 Drag Queens since Nov busted for molesting kids and over 140 pastor/priests having molested kids in the same period… perhaps its time to stop pretending we’re the dangerous ones and look at the fscking wolves telling you they’ll take care of your kids while your out burning pride flags and terrorizing people because you imagine, with no fucking evidence, that they are molesting kids.</p>

<p>One wishes people would bother to hold politicians to account when they flat out lie about things.<br/>

<div class="comment-metadata">
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/24/heritage-foundation-says-that-of-course-gop-will-use-kosa-to-censor-lgbtq-content/#comment-3001165"><time datetime="2023-05-24T15:45:20-07:00">May 24, 2023 at 3:45 pm</time></a>
</div>
<h1 class="comment-title">
"trans" != "LGBTQ" and porn != "LGBTQ content", you liar </h1>
</header>
<div class="comment-content entry-content">
<p>You’re going to a great deal of effort to make it sound like Conservatives “hate teh gays” and it just exposes what a partisan shill you are.</p>
<p>Principally, they’re just trying to keep porn away from kids. That’s probably impossible, but don’t get it twisted, that’s the goal. You’re trying to make it sound like they just want to deny gay people exist, and you’re just lying about it.</p>
<p>The second subject, which the tweet is about is the matter of trans peer pressure/ indoctrination.</p>
<blockquote><p>
In that tweet, Florence Ashley calls out an article on Heritage’s website laughably entitled “How Big Tech Turns Kids Trans” (which, um, is not how any of this works)
</p></blockquote>
<p>Actually, no, there’s a TON of evidence that’s how it works. Or at least that young people identifying as trans is for the vast majority of them a matter of social conditioning — peer pressure and in some cases purposeful conditioning — i.e. it’s a fad. A recent poll said that like 20+% a certain age group identified as “trans”, “nonbinary”, etc, …………<strong>which lol, no they don’t</strong>, but <em>that is seen as the cool thing to say and be now</em>.</p>
<p>Which would be fine except that is sometimes used to justify lie-altering, permanent, often sterilizing procedures. And that’s what Heritage is objecting it to. “Big tech” (really they mean social media) just drives it in the same way it helps drive anorexia.</p>
</div>

Stone</span> <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/user/regularstone/" rel="external nofollow" class="url">(profile)</a> <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span> </div>
<div class="comment-metadata">
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/24/heritage-foundation-says-that-of-course-gop-will-use-kosa-to-censor-lgbtq-content/#comment-3001199"><time datetime="2023-05-24T16:13:08-07:00">May 24, 2023 at 4:13 pm</time></a>
</div>
<h1 class="comment-title">
Re: </h1>
</header>
<div class="comment-content entry-content">
<blockquote><p>
You’re going to a great deal of effort to make it sound like Conservatives “hate teh gays”
</p></blockquote>
<p>It really doesn’t take much effort. Read up on queer history and you’ll find that the people most openly opposed to the recognition of equal rights for queer people over the past few decades have been conservatives⁠—in both politics and religion. That still holds true today. If you think conservatives wouldn’t leap at the chance to undo <em>Obergefell</em>, you’re not paying attention.</p>
<blockquote><p>
they’re just trying to keep porn away from kids
</p></blockquote>
<p>The phrase “trans content” can include porn, yes. But unless that’s specified, you can safely assume that the phrase refers to any kind of content involving trans people in some way that is supportive and respectful of trans people⁠—including accurate information about medical treatments for trans people and online communities for trans people to talk about their lives with one another.</p>
<blockquote><p>
You’re trying to make it sound like they just want to deny gay people exist
</p></blockquote>
<p>Yes, that’s pretty much one of their goals. Why else do you think conservatives keep bristling at things like sports teams celebrating Pride, books with queer characters being in school and public libraries, and gay characters (no matter how incidental) showing up in Disney movies?</p>
<blockquote><p>
there’s a TON of evidence that’s how it works
</p></blockquote>
<p>No, there isn’t. The only “evidence” you and your transphobic brother-in-arms Hyman Rosen have ever shown to back such a claim is a bunch of third-hand stories spread by known transphobes who most certainly have an anti-trans agenda. Until you can provide something more than anecdotal stories that may not even be true, you can’t say you have evidence of “Big Tech” transing anyone’s gender, let alone the gender of a given child.</p>
<p>And even if some people identify as trans or non-binary when they’re not, so what? They all deserve the freedom and safety to question their gender identity⁠—regardless of whatever conclusion they ultimately reach.</p>
<blockquote><p>
“Big tech” … just drives it in the same way it helps drive anorexia.
</p></blockquote>
<p>Prove it with actual evidence beyond “Jesse Singal said she heard from a friend that a kid of a friend of theirs had their gender transed by Twitter”.</p>
</div>

<div id="comment-3002191" data-comment-date="20230525203551" class="comment by-user comment-author-regularstone odd alt parent community-rated-insightful" data-depth="4">
<article id="div-comment-3002191" class="comment-body">
<button class="thread-level"><span class="screen-reader-text">Threaded</span><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 20 18"><use xlink:href="#icon-comments-inline" /></svg> [4]</button>

<div class="rated-insightful"><span class="screen-reader-text">This comment has been deemed insightful by the community.</span></div>
</div>
<div class="comment-author vcard">
<img alt src="https://i0.wp.com/www.techdirt.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/20220227_PissedOff_2x.png?resize=56%2C56&ssl=1" class="avatar avatar-120 photo" height="120" width="120" /><span class="fn">Stephen T. Stone</span> <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/user/regularstone/" rel="external nofollow" class="url">(profile)</a> <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span> </div>
<div class="comment-metadata">
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/24/heritage-foundation-says-that-of-course-gop-will-use-kosa-to-censor-lgbtq-content/#comment-3002191"><time datetime="2023-05-25T13:35:51-07:00">May 25, 2023 at 1:35 pm</time></a>
</div>
<h1 class="comment-title">
Re: Re: Re: </h1>
</header>
<div class="comment-content entry-content">
<blockquote><p>
did you think the accusation was tech companies were doing the surgeries?
</p></blockquote>
<p>Did you?</p>
<p>You can whine and bitch about “Big Tech” all you want here. But the idea that social media services are even remotely responsible for a rise in the number of trans people in the world is ridiculous. Think about this: When the number of gay people in the world seemed to increase in the years after Ellen DeGeneres came out, do you think that was because people thought being gay was “trendy”? Because you might want to remember that Ellen sacrificed her sitcom for the sake of coming out publicly as gay, and gay people were (and still are) targets of violence and hatred even after Ellen came out.</p>
<p>It’s not that Ellen made people think “hey, being gay is cool” or Twitter made people think “hey, being trans is cool”. In fact, it’s largely not “cool” in the context of American society. Look at Florida: That state is doing everything it can to turn the lives of trans people into a living nightmare⁠—to make sure that any trans person in Florida either flees the state, goes back in the closet, or kills themselves. Being queer in 2023 isn’t necessarily as bad as it was in 1993, but it’s not as if queer people are accepted/tolerated across the nation. People still get physically assaulted for being queer. Anti-queer parents still do horrible things to their children if their children come out as queer. To act like being queer is some “hot new fad” is to ignore the fact that being openly queer in the United States is akin to painting a target on one’s back.</p>
<p>The number of visibly out queer people isn’t due to social media (or anything else) turning queerness into a “fad”. It’s due to people feeling that much braver about coming out⁠—even in a society that openly despises queer people. People were always queer; maybe they didn’t have the words or the courage to express it, but their queerness was always part of themselves. They didn’t pick it up on the streets like it was a drug and they didn’t choose to be queer like they chose what shirt to wear on a given day. <strong>Queerness isn’t a fad and social media isn’t making it one.</strong></p>
<p>I mean, who would willingly want to join a population demographic that is actively maligned by a significant part of society?</p>
</div>

<div id="comment-3002073" data-comment-date="20230525152443" class="comment even community-rated-insightful" data-depth="2">
<article id="div-comment-3002073" class="comment-body">
<button class="thread-level"><span class="screen-reader-text">Threaded</span><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 20 18"><use xlink:href="#icon-comments-inline" /></svg> [2]</button>
<header class="comment-meta">
<div class="comment-rated">
<div class="rated-insightful"><span class="screen-reader-text">This comment has been deemed insightful by the community.</span></div>
</div>
<div class="comment-author vcard">
<img alt src="https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/7cc83c6ed2e55859ff61a200855b6eca?d=identicon&s=240" class="avatar avatar-120" /><span class="fn">Anonymous Coward</span> <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span> </div>
<div class="comment-metadata">
<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/24/heritage-foundation-says-that-of-course-gop-will-use-kosa-to-censor-lgbtq-content/#comment-3002073"><time datetime="2023-05-25T08:24:43-07:00">May 25, 2023 at 8:24 am</time></a>
</div>
<h1 class="comment-title">
Re: </h1>
</header>
<div class="comment-content entry-content">
<p>Do I gotta get the chart of how left-handed people exploded in population after we stopped trying to “correct” them, and then stopped growing?</p>
<p>It’s not conditioning, or grooming, or whatever. It’s giving words to explain how these people feel, and those people feeling safe or emboldened to express themselves. I don’t see why it’s unbelievable that 80% of the population identifies with their birth/doctor assigned gender (which is the flipside to 20% being trans or nonbinary). It’s more than I’d think, but, eh, not a stretch.</p>
<p>Plus, you do realize nonbinary just means you feel that you don’t fit into either the man or woman box, right? A lot of nonbinary people even still use the same pronouns they did all their lives. It’s a personal feeling, and shouldn’t be attacked any more than personal faith.</p>
<p>(By the way, I’m PRETTY sure the poll you’re referencing is actually “20% LGBTQ”, which, if you spend time in any city in America, makes 100% sense to be the natural levels, unrestrained by authoritarian codes.)</p>
<p>Yes, I’m sure SOME kids are pretending or falsely believe they’re trans to feel like they fit in with their friends. But… that’s, uh, any social phenomenon, good or bad or neutral. I sure didn’t like football or Family Guy growing up, but I absolutely pretended to in order to gel with my friends. But the rest of them did, and still do.</p>
<p>And, most permanent forms of gender-affirming care simply aren’t performed on minors, unless the minor clearly needs it to prevent suicide. Which is, like, I don’t know, less than 10 a year? It’s not a lot. So, even if you suppose one of those kids each year wants to detrans, that’s a 1/10 “failure”… There are other lifesaving surgeries that have a higher failure rate, where failure is, well, an earlier death.</p>
<p>Finally, keep in mind that the first step the Nazis took in controlling society was not cracking down on Jewish people, trade unions, or Communists, even as they openly railed against them. No, in fact, it was gay and trans people they pursued, jailed, and killed. The first books they burned? All LGBT research or diaries. One of the first sex reassignment surgeries was performed in Weimar Germany, much to the disgust of the Nazi party. It’s likely the Nazis set back LGBT rights and understanding decades. Now, Republicans and international conservative allies are trying to do the same.</p>
<p>Ask yourself if you REALLY want to be on the same side as the Nazis on, well, anything. This isn’t mere name-calling either, it’s the exact playbook. Not a metaphor or exaggeration.</p>
</div>

readabilityObject.title: Heritage Foundation Says That Of Course GOP Will Use KOSA To Censor LGBTQ Content
readabilityObject.content:
from the democratic-support-censoring-lgbtq-speech dept

We’ve talked a lot about KOSA, the “Kids Online Safety Act” that has massive bipartisan support in Congress. The latest version was introduced with 26 Senators as sponsors or co-sponsors. We’ve explained over and over again how the bill is unconstitutional and will actually do a lot to harm kids.

Of course, like so many of these “bipartisan” anti-internet bills that have bipartisan support, the support on each side of the aisle is based on a very different view of how the bill will be used in practice. We went through this last year with the AICOA antitrust bill. Democrats supported it (falsely) believing that it would magically increase competition, while Republicans were gleefully talking about how they were going to use it to force websites to host their propaganda.

Now, with KOSA, again you have Democrats naively (and incorrectly) believing that because it’s called the “Kids Online Safety Bill” it will magically protect children, even though tons of experts have made it clear it will actually put them at greater risk.

Meanwhile, Republicans are now freely admitting that they’re going to use KOSA to force websites to censor LGBTQ content. They’re literally proud of it. The Heritage Foundation, which at least used to have some principled stances before being taken over by culture warriors without any principles, is bragging about how it will use KOSA in this manner:

In that tweet, Florence Ashley calls out an article on Heritage’s website laughably entitled “How Big Tech Turns Kids Trans” (which, um, is not how any of this works), and includes this paragraph:

Lawmakers can also help. Raising the minimum age for internet use (as the Child Online Privacy and Protection Act would do) may be one way to protect kids from online harms. Another step in the right direction would be to prohibit the sexual exploitation of minors and the promotion of content that poses risks to minors’ physical and mental health (which the Kids Online Safety Act would do). If we seek to protect kids online, we must guard against the harms of sexual and transgender content.

Ashley, correctly calls out that they’re openly admitting how they’ll use KOSA to censor content. And Heritage replies in a quote tweet doubling down that this is exactly their plan:

Yes we do. Keeping trans content away from children is protecting kids. No child should be conditioned to think that permanently damaging their healthy bodies to try to become something they can never be is even remotely a good idea.

Leaving aside that this framing is utter nonsense, it’s also none of lawmakers’ business what individuals and their doctors decide is the healthiest way forward for anyone.

So, um, seeing as over a dozen Democratic Senators, including Richard Blumenthal, Ben Ray Lujan, Tammy Baldwin, Amy Klobuchar, Gary Peters, John Hickenlooper, Chris Murphy, Chris Coons, Brian Schatz, Mark Warner, Peter Welch, Maggie Hasan, Dick Durbin, Sheldon Whitehouse, and Bob Casey are supporting, can anyone ask them why they’re supporting a bill that Republicans are saying directly they will use to silence LGBTQ speech?

Again, the enforcement mechanism in the bill is that state Attorneys General get to bring lawsuits against websites for not removing such “harmful” content. And if you don’t believe that there are GOP state AGs itching to bring exactly these lawsuits, you haven’t been paying attention.

I get that Blumenthal and Klobuchar have both made it clear that they don’t care one bit about how Republicans will use their bills to take away rights of the public, but could someone ask the others on that list why they’re supporting such a bill?

Filed Under: 1st amendment, censorship, gop, kosa, lgbtq, state ags
Companies: heritage foundation
